𓃀 𓂾 󳠊 󳠋 󳠌 󳠍 󳠎 󳠏 󳠐 󳠑 󳠒 󳠓 󳠔 󳠕 󳠖 󳠗 󳠘 󳠚 󳠛 󳠜 󳠝 󳠞 󳠟 󳠠 󳠡

Letter B 𒁀 ⋍ b 𓃀 ظ ⇔ 𓂾 ≠ 𒁁

𓃀 Letter b < mP < prat 𓂘 / protho > 𓂋 𓂧 𓂾 ⲣⲁⲧ (right) foot ⇔ Regel
𓃀 ⲫⲁⲧ ⲫⲁⲧ phat ظ pod ⲣⲁⲧ (p)rat ⲡⲉⲍⲁ peza foot Füße

Many Egyptian words with the character '𓃀' now have a 'b' in its derived coptic forms, or similar bh,ph,p sounds in modern variants of this wanderword '𓃀' (all meaning leg⋍foot)

Ablaut forms of "boot" 👢 🥾 are also very common, presumably because of the prevalence in early syllabaries.

𒁁 BÀD pod 𓃀 𓂾 in 𒄑𒁁 leg or foot of a piece of furniture

𒁕 #da πda poda ∋ BÀD 𒁁

Some of these syllabaries are not fully deciphered yet, prime example being the
# Anatolian Hieroglyphs 𔑛𔑜𔑝𔑡𔑢𔑣𔑚𔑤𔑥𔑦𔑧𔑙
𔑞 𔑠 𔑟 𔑨 𔑩

Naturally feet formed grammatical dual forms where applicable

Superroot with a huge cluster of hundreds of derived and related words in many languages:
pedestrian, 𐀴 𐀪 𐀷 𐀆 ti-ri-po-de = tripod (Linear A), boot, foot, Fuß, ferse, verse …

many similar words to foot, leg, thigh, calf:
𓊪 𓂧 𓂾 𓄹 /pod/ “knee” √bent: beuğt > fuđ, afuḍ @ Berber

𒀀𒈾 𒊺 𒁉𒄿𒋗 a-na še pí-i-šu : on his feet < podi:pentos: 5-toes 𒁉𒄿

POD/BOOT

A long/complete reading of 𓃀 as pod/boot is supported by 𓂾
𓊪 𓂧 𓊃 = 𓂾 𓏤 𓆱 𓏤 box ⋍ 𓂾 𓋴 𓆱 𓏤 basket
𓊪 𓂧 𓋴 𓂾 podes=stamp (right-to-left)
𓇼 Sptern 𓋴𓃀𓄿𓇼𓇳 Sputnik 𓇮𓊪𓂧𓏏𓇼 Spitzen 𓇼 𓊪𓏏[𓇯](𓇯)𓀭 Jupiter

Most of all we know the coptic readings of '𓃀' :
𓃀 ⲫⲁⲧ phat ⲣⲁⲧ (p)rat ⲡⲉⲍⲁ peza (foot)

and the Egyptian rebus
𓃀 | place | ቦታ bota!

BEIN

A long/old/complete reading of 𓃀 as bein is supported by
* 𓋁 𓃀 𓏏 𓈉 ⋍ 𓅱 𓃀 𓈖 𓏌 𓅱 𓇳 levante (east)
* 𓃀 𓏏 𓊌 brick 𐎍𐎁𐎐𐎚 lbnt! > 𒋞 libittu ܠܒܬܐ ləḇettā bata
* Manetho's rendering of the name

Qa'a Biénechês

BEND BENT PART

These two readings are not in conflict but instead form the core of a widely applied duality:

1 𓂾 ein Bein (√bend 𓃀 bīr 𐰋𐰃𐰼 bare foot)
2 𓃀𓃀 bīnī binary
2 𓃀𓃀 beide Poden (both boots / feet)
2 𓃀𓃀 a pair:

𒅆𒅆 beide Augen bad
𒅆𒅆 bad₅ ≈ beat in 𒅆𒅆𒅆𒅆 bad₅bad₅ “defeat” #dabdû •beat (in battle) dual duplication

PAIR ⇔ PART

An 'r' component is suggested by:
𓃀 پیر pair | Urdu
𓃀 पैर pair | Hindi
𓃀 perna Latin => pierna Spanish
𓃀 ⲫⲁⲧ ⋍ ⲣⲁⲧ prat
𓋴 𓃀 𓇼 𓏤 𓂧 𓍯 𓅱 𓇼 | morning star | צפרא צַפְרָא ṣap̄rā > صَبَاح ṣabāḥ (𓂧 𓍯 𓅱 diva / star ) sambet

A synthesis and origin of these forms could be "bend" as in:

mopendé “foot” @ Bantu
mbíén “leg” @ Bantu
aboñ abɔ́ŋ “knee” @ Bantu

𓐍 𓆼 𓄿 𓅓 𓂢 | bend (arm in respect), bow down | krümmen √krumm => circle
𓐍 𓆼 𓄿 𓃀 𓏴 | be bent (of arm) | •krümmbend (ambi jambe 𓃀)
𓂾 κάμπη kámpē gamba jambe: bent.
𓂾 κάμπη kámpē gon knee cramp.
𓅙𓃀𓏏𓊌 brick 𐎍𐎁𐎐𐎚 l'bnt! > 𒋞 libittu ܠܒܬܐ ləḇettā bata@Malay
𓂝𓎸𓃀 unite = obediní обедини́ +++ פֿאַרבינדן far𓃀bindn !!
and or giving rise to ambivalence:
𓃀 𓎛 𓊃 𓄑 𓃔 | calf | ⲙⲁⲥⲉ mᴮase 𒀫 būru™

Limb limp 𓃀 Jambe jump ( see M/B ll/j/y/λ Ambivalence )

To see that this is not a somewhat arbitrary subset, look at the whole dictionary

𓃀⋍𓊹 (banner) in
𒆍𒀭𒊏𒆠 Gate-der-Götter Bab.Ilon
𓃀𓃀𓂋𓏤𓈉 Babel

𓃀 þ.d ⇔ (p)r.d 𓂋𓂧𓂾 right foot @ road𓈐
⇔ 𓂋 prego preach petition present
russian 'р'='r' прот prot
(p)road=path≠trasse,strasse causative?

𓊪 𓂧 𓂾 𓄹 knee pod > fuđ, afuḍ @ Berber (knee)

ⲣⲁⲧ (p)rat/pod is maybe the central word in dissecting how 'ⲣ' came to be read as p in the West and r in the east!

Suggested reading: 𒉽𒄬Pap-Half = 𒉽𒄬PaDemi (pod/foot)

As always the original form might have being more complex, and related to jamb jump jambone.

The other original form 'jambone' might be connected to the other larg 'leg cluster' shin:
Schienbein SNB⋍JMB jamb jump jambe gumbo numbu@Franc/Bantu
sune : leg, shin 𒋙 šù ⇔ Schuhen ashi : leg, foot, pace, gait ashi : leg ato-ashi : hind leg (anti-) mukouzune : shin, front of lower leg

Even though the main reading of 𓃀 as b/p is very clear, as infix determinative in context it supports these readings:
𓂾 ⋍ 𓋴𓃀𓏘 šepíke Šėpìkė? šėpikė? ϣⲟⲡ, pike
𓂾 ⋍ 𓋴𓃀𓏘 ϭⲁⲗⲟϫ σκέλος skélos (leg) skeleton
𓂾 ⋍ 𓋴𓃀𓏘 سپل sapal hoof
𓂾 ⋍ 𓋴𓃀𓏘 sċanca < टङ्क ṭaṅka > shank > shin, ankle
𓂾 ⋍ 𓋴𓃀𓏘 ϭⲁⲗⲁⲩϫ calauč ϭⲁⲗⲟϫ caloč the leg : lug@ Kush
Finnish: jalka
Estonian: jalg leg
لنگ leng leg limb limp
लङ्ग laṅga “lame" => long langsam
𓂾 laṅga > l'angle ankle
𓂾 legs > *leys- “to track, pursue; track, furrow, trace, trail”
𓂾 lokolo “leg” @ Bantu

Reverse Regel

𓄙 Re reverse ferse
𓄙 re רֶגֶל régel leg@rind reverse
𓂋 𓂧 𓂾 | foot | ⲣⲁⲧ ⲣⲁⲧ phret ⲫⲁⲧ
𓂋 𓂧 𓂾 | foot | ⲣⲁⲧ.al ⇔ רֶגֶל régel

English Leg ⇔ legal ⋍ Lugal Regel German/Hebrew רֶגֶל régel הָלַךְ halákh walk

The cuneiform orthography paib 𒉺𒅁 and 𒉽𒄬 Pap… are probably just renderings of a half-sound pb/pf (like German: Pfoten)

𓃀 ⲫⲁⲧ phat ظ pod ⲣⲁⲧ butiao 跳 (thigh) ظ beta

𓃀 mBein compare vEIn wain venes ƃþėn by vs ƥleɠ.ƥoeđ 𓂾jambone𓄹𓄻⇔schien-ion! pod,ped,feet ב𓊪 Bethar 𓉐

𓃀 ⋍ punch ⋍ 5 :
𓃀 ⋍ POTENZ ⋍ Power in Sumerian script

PART

π form of 𓂋 𓂧 𓂾 | foot

𒁉 BI = BE ⋍ 𒁁𒁁 BÀD in Akkadian font

The list of words derived from the strong Eurasian/PIE 𓃀 POD/Bein/pair𓃀𓃀 root is most exhaustive:

𓄿 𓊪 𓂧 𓂻 | rush forward | a'pod => avit à vue avvisto

3961 πατέ tread(tret), trample upon
ƥατøī foot⇔pod⇔pat path of
ⲫⲁⲧ/ⲣⲁⲧ => ptread > tread

2662 καταπατέ trample under foot
καταƥατøī kata.foot ƥατ™ podie

5286 ὑποπόδιον a footstool
hύƥοƥoδιοn hypο.podiοn

5348 φθάν anticipate, precede, arrive
phthάn phthan √pod.an DE

1704 ἐμπεριπατέ walk about in a place
ἐmƥεrιƥατøī em.peri.podie/pheatέ ++

2899 κράσπεδον the fringe, edge
κrάsƥεδοn kreis.pedοn 𓊖𓐍𓃀

3960 πατάσσ strike
⇔ patt, put, push put vs pod !
⇔ punt: point, punkt puck

305 ἀναβαίν go up, mount, ascend
ana.bein = an.steig'

576 ἀποβαίν go or come out of, disembark, result
apo.bαin apο.bain ab.bein ™

1684 ἐμβαίν embark
ἐmbαin em.Bein ^^ em.βoot boat 𓊝 shâphoina ال سفينة

𓋴 𓍿 𓊪 𓂻 | leap up | … 𓊪 𓂻 پریدن paridan паридан pular пры́гать (prýgatʹ) प्रवते pravate πηδάω pēdáō

perpette bear

1 𓂾 ein Bein √bend ⇔ an angle 𓌚 ⇔ ἀναβαίν

𓋴 𓃀 /𓂾 Gebein ≠ Schopen 𓋴 𓃀 𓏘 ϣⲟⲡ šop 𓋴 𓃀 /𓂾 Gebein ƙafa @ Hausa 𓄗

This leads to an interesting approach of cluster analysis: dependent probability of one phoneme cluster (b…p) given a random word and one attested in Egyptian. => Did the Egyptian language have measurable influence on neighbouring languages outside of its family? Or represent instances of a far reaching lingua franca continuum of the Copper age?
